author: JASON SILVERSTEIN
title: Guantanamo Bay detainee reported as ISIS suicide bomber
text:
Former Guantanamo Bay detainee who won $1 million settlement for mistreatment reported as ISIS suicide bomber Guantanamo Bay detainee reported as ISIS suicide bomber NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   12:04 PM 
A former Guantanamo Bay detainee from Britain, who was awarded more than $1 million for mistreatment there, may have committed a suicide bombing at an army base in Iraq this week, according to reports. 
ISIS on Tuesday identified Jamal al-Harith as the militant who attacked a coalition force in Mosul. The terror group released photos of al-Harith and claimed his bombing led to several deaths. 
ISIS’ report of the attack could not be independently verified. But al-Harith’s brother confirmed the authenticity of the images ISIS released, and said his kin “wasted his life.” 
“It is him, I can tell by his smile,” the brother, Leon Jameson, told the Times of London . 
“If it is true then I’ve lost a brother, so another family (member) gone.” 
Reuters cited three Western security forces who said al-Harith, 50, was the suicide bomber. 
Al-Harith was born in Manchester as Ronald Fidler and changed his name after converting to Islam in the 1990s. 
He was held at Guantanamo Bay for two years, without charges, over alleged links to Osama bin Laden and after authorities learned he visited a Taliban prison in Afghanistan. 
He was one of four British detainees released in 2004 after a massive lobbying campaign from the United Kingdom government and some national media organizations. A photo released by ISIS of Jamal al-Harith, who the terror group identified as a suicide bomber. (AP) 
After his release, al-Harith claimed he was tortured in the U.S. military prison, and he joined 16 other men in a lawsuit against the British government for allegedly being complicit in their abuse. 
The group won a cash settlement in 2010, with al-Harith reportedly receiving about 1 million pounds, or $1.25 million. 
It remains unclear when al-Harith may have joined ISIS. The British Foreign Office, which has not confirmed al-Harith’s involvement in the attack, said in a statement it is “extremely difficult to confirm the whereabouts and status of British nationals” in the countries where ISIS operates. 
Democrats say Obama must 'deprive' Trump of using Guantanamo Bay 
The news of al-Harith’s attack led to some British news outlets, particularly the Daily Mail, castigating former Prime Minister Tony Blair for overseeing the militant’s release. 
Blair issued a statement acknowledging he coordinated the release, but not the massive payout years later, and noted the immense public pressure back then to let al-Harith walk free. 
“The fact is that this was always a very difficult situation where any Government would have to balance proper concern for civil liberties with desire to protect our security, and we were likely to be attacked whatever course we took,” Blair wrote. 
“But those who demanded their release should not be allowed to get away with now telling us that it is a scandal that it happened.”
